awd_titl_txt: Anthropological Investigation of Social Determinants of Knowledge
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Lawrence Bobo at Harvard University, and Drs. Tricia Redeker-Hepner and Heather Smith-Cannoy at Arizona State University, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the social conditions of knowledge production across social initiatives at regional police departments and nonprofit organizations. In the past several decades, workplace programs have increased in popularity promising to produce more favorable institutional outcomes. However, some scholars have criticized these efforts as offering individual solutions for structural problems, and, we understand little of how those involved respond to the initiatives and how their responses challenge ongoing issues. The proposed research will address these questions via a comparative, multi-site ethnographic analysis of social initiatives across two distinct institutions. An ethnographic understanding of how systemic issues persist within these contexts has the potential to improve outcomes. 

The goal of this proposed study is to contribute to theory and public understanding of social determinants of knowledge within the workplace. The project aims to do so by collecting ethnographic data—including observations of workplace trainings, analyses of program documents, and semi-structured interviews with trainers, employees, and hiring and training managers—from multiple regional police departments and nonprofit organizations. This research will ask how various conceptualizations contribute to participant recruitment and how they compare across institutions; how challenges are managed; and how trainers and employees negotiate participation. It will build upon growing social scientific efforts to examine the conditions of collective knowledge production and will thereby offer fresh insight into the relation between social determinants of knowledge and structural outcomes. Furthermore, this project’s comparative framework will facilitate theorizing about how systemic issues vary across institutions, as well as how uniform policies may not translate across different types of organizations. Through these contributions, this study seeks to enrich public and scholarly conversations about how to best promote more favorable structural outcomes in the workplace.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF SPRF allowed the PI, Dr. Jessica Katzenstein, to complete a new research project and gain invaluable professional training as a postdoctoral fellow at Arizona State University's Global Human Rights Hub and Harvard University's Inequality in America Initiative, with the support of co-PIs Dr. Tricia Redeker-Hepner and Dr. Heather Smith-Cannoy at Arizona State and Dr. Lawrence Bobo at Harvard. The primary objective of Katzenstein's project was to investigate the conditions of knowledge production across workplace social initiatives in the Phoenix, Arizona metropolitan area. Through ethnographic research - including semi-structured interviews with police officers and leaders across multiple organizations in the region - she contributed to social scientific understandings and public knowledge about such initiatives in multiple ways.

One key finding of this study involves the importance of tailoring workplace social initiatives to regional context. Many employees found social initiatives developed on the East Coast or by national organizations to be ill-suited to the issues they sought to address and the specific challenges they faced in Arizona's unique environment. Instead, these workers advocated for workplace training programs grounded in Southwestern concerns and histories. This finding contributes to Intellectual Merit by enriching social scientific analysis of the social determinants of knowledge. This study demonstrates that national training programs not only must be translated locally, as many scholars have shown, but also may be rejected altogether if their knowledge categories diverge from local understandings. This finding also contributes to Broader Impacts by underlining the difficulties of applying uniform programmatic templates across institutions and social geographies. Workplace social initiatives that attempt to implement one-size-fits-all solutions to institutional issues may risk employee backlash and ultimately prove ineffective.

A second key finding from this study involves the ways that leadership disagreements over appropriate knowledge of institutional pasts impact organizations' futures. For leaders who envisioned their organization as aspiring to an ideal model not yet realized, workplace trainings provided an opportunity to advance their aspirations. They asserted that such trainings required engagement with both local and national institutional histories. By contrast, other leaders sought a future that entailed returning to an ideal past, and framed certain workplace social initiatives as unnecessary. Conflicts between these groups over whether particular forms of knowledge would facilitate improved institutional futures eventually led to gridlock in some organizations, and the cessation of workplace social initiatives in others. This finding contributes to Intellectual Merit by illustrating how collective knowledge can serve as not only a unifying force, as scholars have often discussed, but also a fracturing element. This finding contributes to Broader Impacts by demonstrating the long-term effects of high-level disagreements over how to best promote favorable structural outcomes. Institutional futures may be determined by whose visions of appropriate knowledge ultimately prevail.

The PI has presented the findings from this research in multiple outlets, including academic conferences in three countries. She will continue to present and produce both academic and public writing on the social determinants of knowledge.
